title: California's Second Shutdown
summary: Gov. Newsom succumbs to pressure and locks the economy again.. California Gov. Gavin Newsom pressed the panic button on Monday and locked down his state again. The causes of California's Covid-19 "surge" are complex as they are elsewhere, but most areas have ample hospital capacity. Mr. Newsom and other politicians will do more long-term harm to their citizens if they sedate the economy whenever and wherever there's a flare-up.

title: GPB Capital Denies Massachusetts Fraud Claims
summary: The firm rejects accusations concerning statements to investors who put millions in its funds. GPB Capital Holdings LLC has denied fraud and other claims made by Massachusetts securities regulators in May, saying that the state failed to provide evidence to back its case and that it lacked jurisdiction, among other issues.

title: Paper Store Files for Bankruptcy, Hit by Pandemic
summary: Northeast chain of 86 gift stores says coronavirus is the main culprit but Patriots' performance dragged down sales of sports items. Paper Store LLC, a chain of 86 stationery and gift stores located in the Northeast, has filed for bankruptcy and plans to look for a buyer, the latest retailer to resort to chapter 11 as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Why Putin Loves America's Greens
summary: Europe fast-tracks Nord Stream 2 as the left blocks U.S. pipelines.. Democratic politicians have talked tough on Russia since Donald Trump won the Presidency. But when it comes to challenging Moscow, other progressive priorities always seem to take precedence.

title: The Speech Police at Princeton
summary: The cancel culture targets a respected classics professor.. When a Princeton classics professor wrote an article for the Quillette website taking issue with recent faculty demands over race, a storm of criticism descended. This was an opening for President Christopher Eisgruber and other university leaders to remind people that Princeton is a place where speech and debate are cherished. Instead, Princeton is demonstrating how a lack of leadership enables the cancel culture.

title: Hong Kong's Endangered Elections
summary: The Communist Party moves to outlaw any political opposition.. Hong Kong's freedoms shrink by the day, but its people won't give them up without a fight. Beijing fears an embarrassing defeat in the September Legislative Council elections, so it now seeks to outlaw political opposition.

title: Trump Administration Rescinds Rules on Foreign Students Studying Online
summary: Move settles lawsuit brought by Harvard, MIT; returns to the status quo of guidance issued in the spring. The Trump administration has agreed to rescind rules it issued last week barring international students from being in the U.S. if they were taking classes only online, a rare reversal by the government on immigration policy.

title: Can We Find New Governors?
summary: The strange reaction to Ivanka Trump's jobs campaign.. In the upside-down world of modern press coverage, politicians win praise for opportunity-crushing lockdowns while a new White House effort to encourage job seekers is attracting scorn across the media landscape.

title: The Biden Tax Hike Would Be Severe
summary: If the Democrats sweep in November, make sure your lawyer and financial advisers are standing by.. Complain if you must, but we live in a Golden Age of Taxes-the lowest rates we may see for decades. President Trump's 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act lowered rates, widened brackets and simplified preparation. Gazing toward the heavens, one can almost see the smiling face of Ronald Reagan beaming down. Yet like all Golden Ages, this one will end, and we already know the date: Dec. 31, 2025. Barring a miracle, that is when the tax cuts expire and President Obama's American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012 becomes the law of the land once more.

title: The Justices' Wakeup Call to Congress
summary: When it created the CFPB, the legislature gave it immense power. Now, the presidency has a hold of it.. The Supreme Court released an underappreciated decision last month that should teach Congress an important lesson about the danger of relinquishing its powers. Seila Law v. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau asked if it was constitutional for Congress to constrain the president's ability to fire the CFPB director, allowing removal only for "inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office." In a 5-4 decision, the court said no.

title: New York City Coronavirus Infection Rate Is Rising Among Younger People
summary: Shift suggests Covid-19 is spreading by people moving around and socializing more. Increasing infections among New York City residents in their 20s and 30s indicate the new coronavirus is spreading by people moving around and socializing more, city officials said Tuesday.

title: The Day That Shook the Earth
summary: The Trinity nuclear test brought peace in 1945 and proliferation in decades to follow.. Seventy-five years ago, on July 16, 1945, the world's first atomic explosion, code-named "Trinity," jolted the New Mexico desert just before dawn.

title: A Grand Bargain to Reopen Public Schools
summary: It's in students' best interests to go back to class. Teachers will need hazard pay.. Reopening public schools has moved-appropriately-to the center of national debate. U.S. public education from pre-K through 12th grade is a $680 billion yearly enterprise, involving about 51 million students and more than six million teachers and support staff, not to mention tens of millions of parents. If schools don't reopen this fall, students will suffer, parents will face difficult choices, and the economic recovery will be hobbled. But if schools are reopened hastily, without adequate preparation, the public-health consequences will be dire.

title: Court Rejects Multimillion-Dollar Weinstein Settlement
summary: Judge says proposed agreement seeks to create class action despite accusers' varied experiences. A federal judge rejected a multimillion-dollar settlement of sexual-misconduct cases against Harvey Weinstein, saying the proposed agreement improperly attempts to create a class action.

title: Americans and the Virus
summary: A nation searches for the happy medium between lockdown and letting it rip.. Your odds of dying because you boarded a commercial flight just went up at least 44-fold, according to a statistics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. If your risk of death was 1 in 34 million before, now it's 1 in 770,000, or 1 in 540,000 if the middle seat is occupied, thanks to coronavirus.

title: 'Cancel Culture': Views From the Campus
summary: Students debate the merits of the latest export from the universities.. Editor's note: In this Future View, students discuss the merits of "cancel culture." Next week we'll ask, "Will the recent privacy-related concerns with TikTok stop you from using the app?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before July 21. The best responses will be published that night.

title: 'To Bring the Good News to All Nations' Review: Global Awakening
summary: Evangelicals make up perhaps a quarter of the U.S. population. What are their views on global affairs and American foreign policy?. Most Americans are acquainted with evangelical advocacy on controversial social issues, but few have any idea what evangelicals-who make up around a quarter of the U.S. population-think about other topics. Among those topics: global affairs.

title: Jump in Coronavirus Cases Could Jeopardize Oil Market Recovery, OPEC Says
summary: Cartel sees the global economy shrinking by 3.7% this year-more than previously forecast. Even a record-breaking rise in oil demand next year won't be enough to spur a recovery back to pre-coronavirus levels, according to the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Vox Media Prepares to Lay Off Some Furloughed Employees
summary: Media company's lucrative events business has been hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic. Vox Media, the publisher of New York magazine, the Verge and SB Nation, is preparing for a round of layoffs as its financial situation continues to suffer from the economic effects of the coronavirus pandemic, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Justice Ginsburg Hospitalized for Possible Infection
summary: Supreme Court says she is resting comfortably after undergoing an endoscopic procedure. WASHINGTON-Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg was admitted to a Baltimore hospital Tuesday for the treatment of a possible infection and will remain for a few days to receive intravenous antibiotics, the Supreme Court said.

title: Hospitals Stock Up on Covid-19 Drugs to Prepare for Second Wave in Fall
summary: Health systems build up inventories of antivirals like remdesivir and common drugs like acetaminophen; shortages of some ICU meds remain. Hospitals across the country are stocking up on drugs for treating Covid-19, hoping to avoid another scramble for critical medications should a second wave of the virus threaten new drug shortages.

title: Best Buy to Require Shoppers to Wear Masks Inside Stores
summary: Electronics chain joins Starbucks and Costco in requiring masks to combat spread of coronavirus. Best Buy Co. will require customers to wear face coverings inside all U.S. stores to protect against the new coronavirus, including in places without mask mandates.

title: Moderna's Covid-19 Vaccine Moves to Bigger Study
summary: New U.S.-funded trial would seek 30,000 subjects and could deliver answer by year-end. New details about the first human study of Moderna Inc.'s experimental coronavirus vaccine emerged Tuesday, which researchers said reinforced their decision to take the shot into a large, decisive clinical trial scheduled to start in late July.

title: Subway Riders Clash Over Safety Measures Amid Pandemic
summary: Resume Subscription. More than two months after New York City's subway system started closing every night for cleaning during the coronavirus pandemic, trains are once again filling up with commuters heading to work, sparking tension among riders who are butting heads about safety procedures.

title: Bari Weiss Quits New York Times Opinion, Alleging Hostile Work Environment
summary: Departure comes weeks after resignation of editorial-page chief James Bennet. Bari Weiss, a high-profile editor and writer for the New York Times opinion section, resigned Monday, citing what she said was unchecked bullying from colleagues and depicting the news organization as a place where the free exchange of ideas was no longer welcome.

title: 'Brave New World' Review: Reviving a Cautionary Future
summary: Peacock's adaptation of Aldous Huxley's 1932 novel makes mostly ill-advised departures from its source.. 'Brave New World," which arrives along with NBC's Peacock streaming service Wednesday, presumes no small degree of literary license. It spends so much time reveling in its own aesthetic that dramatic momentum becomes an afterthought. At the same time, there are real ideas contained within the nine-part series. Some of them are actually in the book.

title: JPMorgan Sets Aside Billions to Cover Coronavirus Loan Losses
summary: America's biggest bank posted a second-quarter profit of $4.7 billion, a 51% drop. JPMorgan Chase & Co. set aside $10.47 billion to cover potential losses on loans to borrowers hurt by the coronavirus pandemic, cutting its second-quarter profit in half.

summary: Investors digest results from JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup for insights into the health of the economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average raced higher late in the trading day, clinching a third straight session of gains and its biggest point and percentage advance of the month.

title: Biden Unveils $2 Trillion Plan to Combat Climate Change
summary: Democratic presidential candidate would use climate policy as an economic-development tool over four years. Former Vice President Joe Biden unveiled a $2 trillion proposal Tuesday to combat climate change, calling for a bigger investment and faster action than he backed during the Democratic primaries earlier this year.

title: Israelis Fear Schools Reopened Too Soon as Covid-19 Cases Climb
summary: Outbreaks in schools had infected at least 1,335 students and 691 staff by Monday since the reopening in early May. TEL AVIV-Some Israeli public-health officials are blaming the country's decision to reopen schools in May for helping fuel a large new wave of coronavirus infections that has prompted authorities to shut down sections of the economy once again.

title: Wells Fargo Swings to First Loss in More Than a Decade
summary: San Francisco-based bank loses $2.38 billion in the second quarter as coronavirus pummels economy. Wells Fargo & Co. posted its first quarterly loss in more than a decade and socked away nearly $10 billion to prepare for a wave of loan defaults.

title: Fed's Bullard Says Economy Can Rebound in Second Half of Year
summary: St. Louis Fed president says upbeat outlook can be achieved building on experience in dealing with the coronavirus crisis. Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President James Bullard said Tuesday that as the economy adapts to the coronavirus pandemic, a solid recovery and a substantial decline in what is now a very high unemployment rate are both possible.

title: LeBron James Is Going Back to Disney World
summary: The NBA is returning to the place where he played the biggest game of his young life. More than 20 years after a 'heartbreaking' loss, James has another title in mind.. LeBron James could see it happening as the ball left his hands. He was about to hit a buzzer-beater in the biggest game of his life.

title: Here's What To Make Of The Supreme Court Rulings on Trump's Taxes
summary: The possible release of records likely won't be until after the presidential election. The Supreme Court paved the way for a New York prosecutor to enforce a subpoena for President Trump's financial and tax records, but issued a mixed decision in a related case involving subpoenas from Congress.

title: Virginia Congressman Morgan Griffith Tests Positive for Covid-19
summary: Republican is eighth House member known to contract disease caused by new coronavirus. A Republican congressman from Virginia has tested positive for Covid-19, becoming the eighth member of the U.S. House of Representatives known to have contracted the disease.

title: The Staying Inside Guide: A Phonograph Online
summary: The Library of Congress's National Jukebox website is a trove of classical and popular music recordings from the early 20th century.. With all the new music flooding the internet, it's easy to forget the wealth of early 20th-century recordings produced on cylinders or shellac discs (called 78s) that can also be enjoyed there. They document historical performances of classical repertoire and, equally important, the popular music of a century ago. The overriding character of this popular music is happy, often ragtime-influenced tunefulness and lyrics brimming with clever rhymes and wordplay.

title: 'This Is Not a Normal Recession': Banks Ready for Wave of Coronavirus Defaults
summary: JPMorgan, Citigroup and Wells Fargo stockpile $28 billion to cover potential loan losses. The largest U.S. banks signaled that the worst of the coronavirus recession is yet to come, opting to stow away tens of billions of dollars to prepare for an expected wave of loan losses.

title: Lost Cause of Those Confederate Monuments
summary: Here in metropolitan Richmond, Va., where monuments have been biting the dust with fierce regularity, historic tourism is a big deal.. William Toti's "Stalin and the Confederacy" (op-ed, July 10) provides a unique view of Confederate statuary: justification for Stalin worship, perhaps the most damning indictment yet. But there is another unique view that has nothing to do with praising the "Lost Cause" and which might bring a measure of unity to this contentious debate.

title: Why We Withdrew the Police Shooting Study
summary: The reason for the retraction had nothing to do with the claims made by Heather Mac Donald.. In her "I Cited Their Study, So They Disavowed It" (op-ed, July 9), Heather Mac Donald claims we retracted our paper on police shootings because the findings "challenge reigning orthodoxies" and we "disowned" our research because she cited it. This is a severe mischaracterization for three reasons. First, I sent the paper in question to Ms. Mac Donald when it was first published. The idea that I would want her to know about my research while at the same time disowning that research when she approvingly wrote of it is nonsensical. Second, Ms. Mac Donald knew the reason for the retraction wasn't her support of the work because I sent her an email clearly stating this point before she published her op-ed. Third, I have not retracted my other work on police shootings, which has also been controversial. An earlier 2019 paper of mine, which found no evidence of anti-black disparities in the likelihood of being fatally shot when controlling for crime rates, also resulted in calls for retraction and positive endorsement by prominent conservative voices, but I continue to uphold that work. The reason for the retraction had nothing to do with the claims made by Ms. Mac Donald. As described in our retraction statement (psyarxiv.com/dj57k), we retracted the paper because we overstepped with the inferences we made from our data; we did not uphold the high standard of drawing careful and measured conclusions that is necessary for scientists studying this important topic. We did not retract the paper due to improper data or analyses, nor is the retraction evidence that police are racially biased.

title: D.C. Had History of Suppressing Black Vote
summary: Focusing on the new state's potential partisan leaning misses the point: Statehood would correct an overt act of racial voter suppression with Reconstruction era roots.. Speaking on the House of Representatives' recent approval of D.C. statehood, which would finally grant statehood and congressional voting representation to over 700,000 D.C. residents, David Rivkin and Lee Casey caution against a "law pushed through for partisan advantage" ("RFK vs. D.C. Statehood," op-ed, July 3).

title: Taxpayer Money Helped to Make Remdesivir
summary: Taxpayers were the angel investors. While Gilead quickly recoups its investment, taxpayers will see no return, only big bills.. Regarding "Virus Drug to Cost $3,120 Per Patient" (U.S. News, June 30): Fanfare for Gilead Sciences Inc.'s "responsible pricing" doesn't acknowledge a $99 million federal investment that saved remdesivir from the scrapheap. Taxpayers were the angel investors. While Gilead quickly recoups its investment, taxpayers will see no return, only big bills.

title: Focus Turns to Other Death Row Inmates
summary: Following first federal execution in 17 years, a judge declined requests to delay the capital punishment of convicted murderers Wesley Ira Purkey and Dustin Lee Honken. After the Trump administration on Tuesday morning carried out the first federal execution since 2003, attention moved to the scheduled executions of two other men Wednesday and Friday.

title: N.J. Senate Committee Clears $10 Billion Borrowing Plan
summary: State tax revenues have plunged amid the coronavirus shutdown and recession. The New Jersey Senate budget committee approved legislation giving the state the authority to borrow nearly $10 billion to cover a growing deficit stemming from the Covid-19 pandemic and economic crisis.

title: German Fitness Chain RSG Wins Gold's Gym Bankruptcy Auction
summary: RSG Group topped a stalking-horse offer for Gold's Gym with a $100 million bid for the Dallas-based gym operator. RSG Group GmbH, operator of Germany's McFit fitness clubs, has won an auction to acquire Gold's Gym International Inc. out of bankruptcy for $100 million.

title: Fed's Brainard Sees Substantial Economic Risks and Slow Recovery
summary: 'A thick fog of uncertainty still surrounds us, and downside risks predominate,' says Fed governor Lael Brainard. A top official at the Federal Reserve said difficulty suppressing the new coronavirus will pose substantial risks for the U.S. economy, including a possible double dip in economic activity, and warned that the nation faces a long, slow recovery even if those hazards are avoided.

title: U.K. to Ban Huawei From 5G Networks Amid China Tensions
summary: British government gives cellular companies until 2027 to remove Chinese firm's technology. LONDON-The British government said it would bar telecom companies from purchasing new equipment made by China's Huawei Technologies Co. for their 5G networks in a further sign of the deteriorating relations between Beijing and the West.

title: Auto Makers Grapple With Worker No-Shows as Covid-19 Cases Surge
summary: GM cuts shift at Missouri plant; Ford ramps up hiring in Kentucky. General Motors Co. and Ford Motor Co. are continuing to struggle with keeping workers on the job as coronavirus cases surge nationwide, forcing the auto-making giants to cut shifts, hire new workers and transfer others to fill vacant roles.

title: Retailers Create New Curbside Shopping Experiences
summary: Stores are responding to reduced foot traffic with revamped window displays, customized sidewalk services. Some stores are trying to turn window shopping into real business during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Amid the Hustle and Bustle of Bangkok, a Piece of Peace and Quiet
summary: A pair of design professionals created a calming and tranquil space high above Thailand's capital city. Ed Ng says he could smell the burning rubble of Bangkok's CentralWorld shopping mall when he visited the city just after the political protests in 2010. The period of civil unrest had caused property values to drop, and Mr. Ng and his partner, Terence Ngan, flew in on the advice of a friend to tour and potentially buy a place. Together Mr. Ng, 51, and Mr. Ngan, 50, also run AB Concept, an interior design and architecture studio with offices in Hong Kong, Taipei and Milan with clients including Four Seasons, Mandarin Oriental and Ritz Carlton. Their firm was recently tapped to design the public areas, amenity floor, standard residential provisions and sales gallery for an Extell development designed by the architecture firm Snøhetta in Manhattan.

title: Tesla Is No Berkshire, but Mom and Pop Might Buy Anyway
summary: Companies joining or departing the S&P 500 tend to rise and fall before the fact, costing index-fund investors. Now Tesla threatens to make a real dent.. The tortoise eventually beats the hare in the stock market.

title: Banks' Energy Boycott Is an Antitrust Problem
summary: Radical groups organize an effort to starve oil and gas companies of capital. That raises prices for consumers.. America's largest financial institutions are picking winners and losers in the energy sector for political reasons-even while the Covid-19 crisis has reduced global oil demand and a price war between Russia and Saudi Arabia has flooded global markets with crude. Under pressure from environmental activists, banks are withholding desperately needed capital from oil and gas companies. In doing so, they put millions of jobs at risk and may even be violating federal antitrust law.

title: 'Hamilton' Loses Its Snob Appeal
summary: Political correctness is a barrier to keep the working class from becoming upwardly mobile.. When I was a new student at Yale in 2015, everyone on campus was talking about the Broadway sensation "Hamilton." "It's amazing," a classmate told me. I had never been to a musical. Neither, as far as I knew, had anyone from my hometown. I searched the internet for tickets: $400-way beyond my budget as a veteran enlisted man attending college on the GI Bill.

summary: Longtime chairman Mike Jackson to fill CEO role permanently, his contract extended through 2022. summary: Move comes after Trump administration approved an upgrade for island's Patriot systems.

summary: Resume Subscription. When choosing the best video clips to promote from around the web, Alphabet Inc.'s Google gives a secret advantage to one source in particular: itself.

title: Why It Seems Like Bullies Are Everywhere-and How to Stop Them
summary: Bullies try to intimidate people they see as weak or vulnerable. Here's how to respond.. American sports teams are doubling down on ambitious real-estate projects, despite the coronavirus pandemic that has shut down most live entertainment from coast to coast.

title: Walking the Coronavirus Containment Tightrope: How Countries Balance Saving Lives and the Economy
summary: Resume Subscription. As the world relaxes its lockdowns against the coronavirus pandemic, the early results range from fragile success to worsening crisis.

title: Biotech Properties Draw Billions of Dollars as Other Real Estate Languishes
summary: Pandemic puts premium on life-sciences space, while undercutting hotels, shopping centers and senior housing. Covid-19 is clobbering hotels, shopping centers and senior housing communities. But the pandemic is providing an extra boost to landlords leasing to biotechnology, pharmaceutical and other life-sciences businesses.

title: Google Cloud Chief Finds Opportunities in Pandemic for Customer Connection
summary: 'Every week, there's a new set of dimensions, and we have to adapt,' said Thomas Kurian. Google Cloud is racing to roll out new features and services aimed at helping its enterprise customers maintain business continuity during the coronavirus pandemic, including a new security product expected to launch Tuesday, said Thomas Kurian, chief executive of the Google LLC unit.

title: Oat-Milk Company Draws Investment From Blackstone-Led Group Including Oprah
summary: Swedish company is selling a roughly 10% stake for $200 million. Swedish oat-milk maker Oatly AB has sold a $200 million stake to a group led by private-equity giant Blackstone Group Inc. that includes Oprah Winfrey, Natalie Portman, former Starbucks Corp. chief Howard Schultz and the entertainment company founded by Jay-Z.

title: Former Luckin Chairman Loses Control of Coffee Chain in Court
summary: Chinese private-equity firm Centurium Capital to have the most voting rights. HONG KONG-Charles Lu, the co-founder and former chairman of Luckin Coffee Inc., has lost control of all his shares in the Chinese coffee chain following a recent court ruling, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Sobering Economic Data From Europe, Asia Dash Hopes for Swift Recovery
summary: A brutal second-quarter contraction in Singapore and a feeble recovery in the U.K. give an early look at the tough climb facing the world economy. Early data from Europe and Asia suggest the recovery from the economic crisis precipitated by the coronavirus pandemic could take longer than originally hoped, with countries facing a long slog to recover lost jobs and income.

title: China's Pain Could Be Google's, Facebook's Gain in India
summary: With China's internet giants locked out of the world's second-most-populous country, U.S. tech sees an opportunity. Chinese firms, used to being atop the internet food chain in Asia, have fallen from their perch in India because of Beijing's diplomatic stumbles-and U.S. firms are looking to climb on.

title: The NFL Is Supposed to Start Soon. It Doesn't Have a Plan Yet.
summary: Training camps are set to open on July 28-and there still isn't a concrete plan for if and how the season will work in 2020. The NFL began the pandemic in an enviable position. The virus shut down every other major sports league, but the country's most popular sport was in its offseason. It had months to plan how to deliver football to its millions of fans in the fall.

title: Private-Debt Fundraising Gains Popularity as Credit Stress Returns
summary: Distressed-debt investing, long neglected by investors, is showing signs it could thrive under the pandemic. Private-credit fundraising returned to popularity in the first half of the year as the coronavirus pandemic gave distressed-debt investors hope that a window of bargain-hunting might be opening.

title: Automatic 401(k) Transfers Gain Traction
summary: Automatically transferring small accounts would reduce cash-outs and potentially save participants an additional $1.5 trillion. When workers change jobs, many cash out their retirement savings, paying taxes and often penalties in the process. A service designed to prevent money from leaving corporate retirement plans when workers switch jobs got a boost Tuesday when large 401(k) record-keeper Alight Solutions LLC disclosed plans to offer it to many large U.S. companies.

title: Universities Cut Oil Investments as Student Activism Builds
summary: Push for large-scale divestment at colleges marks the latest blow to companies; some call it counterproductive. When the University of Michigan's chief financial officer asked the school's Board of Regents in December to authorize a new $50 million oil-and-gas investment, they gave an answer he had never heard before: No.

title: GM Faces Battle in China to Regain Lost Ground
summary: The auto maker has seen its market share erode in a country where it typically records nearly half of its global unit sales. SHANGHAI- General Motors Co. faces a critical test winning back consumers in China, a market integral to its fortunes.

title: Record Numbers of Americans Try to Buy Guns
summary: Buyers and gun store owners cite the coronavirus pandemic, George Floyd's killing and efforts to defund the police. MINNEAPOLIS-Americans are buying guns in record numbers.

title: Virus Turns U.S. Tariffs Into a Sideshow for Luxury Brands
summary: Shareholders are blasé about Washington's threats to impose extra tariffs on French luxury goods, perhaps because China is growing even more crucial for the sector. Investors in designer fashion brands are already ignoring an avalanche of bad news. What harm is a little more?

title: China's Imports and Exports Rebound as Coronavirus Fades in World's Second-Largest Economy
summary: China's trade surplus with the U.S. narrows from a year earlier on rise in agricultural imports. BEIJING-Chinese imports from the U.S. rose for the first time since the new coronavirus emerged earlier this year, showcasing Beijing's post-pandemic purchasing power even as political tension between the world's two largest economies continues to rise.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Roger Stone May Not Appeal Conviction Now That His Sentence Has Been Commuted
summary: 'I'm not a fool; I'm going to be guided by the advice of my lawyers,' he said Monday night. Roger Stone said he might drop his appeal of his conviction, in his most extensive public remarks since President Trump commuted his 40-month sentence Friday, days before he was to report to prison.

title: Fox News's Tucker Carlson Rejects Writer's Posts and Critics' 'Self-Righteousness'
summary: Prime-time host said former writer's racist and misogynist online posts have no connection to 'Tucker Carlson Tonight'. Fox News host Tucker Carlson rejected the racist and misogynist online posts made by his former writer, saying they had no connection to his prime-time show, but warned critics that "self-righteousness also has its costs."

title: Los Angeles Public Schools Won't Open in Fall as Covid-19 Crisis Continues
summary: Superintendent says online-only education to continue as new school year starts Aug. 18. The Los Angeles Unified School District, the nation's second largest, said Monday that it would start the school year online.

title: OPEC Was Under Pressure Even Before Covid-19
summary: The cartel's data released Monday showed that last year it exported cheaper oil and less of it. Even before the coronavirus pandemic upended global oil markets, the influence of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries-and the group's revenues-were under pressure from competitors and the declining value of its crude.

title: Mental Resilience Can Help You Through the Coronavirus Pandemic; Here's How to Build It.
summary: The brain naturally gravitates toward negative thoughts. Here are ways to steel yourself in rocky patches, from deep breathing to caring for others.. With Covid-19 cases rising in the U.S. and the economic outlook uncertain-just when many had hoped things would improve-it can be tough at times not to slide into despair. Rick Hanson, a clinical psychologist and author of the 2018 book, "Resilient," spoke with The Wall Street Journal about how we can build our resilience in challenging times. Dr. Hanson, a senior fellow at the Greater Good Science Center at the University of California, Berkeley draws on neuroscience, psychology and mindfulness training in his work.

title: Ford Reveals New Bronco After 24 Years Off the Market
summary: The revival of the '60s-era off-roader is central to Ford's turnaround efforts. Steve Olliges has raced older Ford Broncos through the desert and has five vintage ones in his garage. But the Ford dealer has never sold one from his showroom in Las Vegas. Instead, he's watched rival Jeep dealers in town peddle thousands of Jeep Wranglers to off-roading enthusiasts over the years.

title: Different Wavelengths: Science Finds Hummingbirds See Ultraviolet Light Invisible to Humans
summary: Resume Subscription.

title: Tech-Stock Rally Isn't Out of Juice Just Yet, Analysts Say
summary: Market watchers remain bullish on technology shares continuing to outperform major indexes amid pandemic. Shares of technology companies have leapt ahead of the broader market, and analysts don't see that changing soon.

title: U.S. 12-Month Deficit Hits $3 Trillion as Virus Stimulus Spending Soars
summary: As share of GDP, deficit is on pace to be the largest since World War II. WASHINGTON-The U.S. budget deficit reached $3 trillion in the 12 months through June as stimulus spending soared and tax revenue plunged, putting the federal government on pace to register the largest annual deficit as a share of the economy since World War II.

title: Trump's Niece Wins Legal Battle Over Tell-All Book
summary: New York judge vacates earlier injunction against Mary Trump, saying any bar against her would 'serve no purpose'. A New York judge dealt the Trump family a loss on Monday, vacating a temporary injunction against President Trump's niece, Mary Trump, and ending a weekslong legal battle to block the release of her tell-all book.

title: Officials Fear Fire Has Damaged Assault Ship Beyond Repair
summary: Amphibious assault ship one of the few in U.S. fleet that can launch F-35 operations. WASHINGTON-The fire aboard the amphibious assault ship USS Bonhomme Richard showed no sign of abating Monday, raising fears that one of the few U.S. Navy ships that can operate like a mini aircraft carrier is damaged beyond repair.

title: New York Lawmakers to Hold Hearings on Impact of Coronavirus
summary: One of the hearings will look at New York hospitals' response to the Covid-19 crisis. Members of the New York Senate and Assembly said Monday they will hold hearings to examine the impact of the coronavirus pandemic in the state, with a focus on its health-care system.
